name: Subaru Impreza 555
details_html: Launched in 1993, the turbocharged all-wheel-drive Impreza 555 became an instant icon, carrying Colin McRae to his 1995 World Title and Subaru’s first manufacturers’ championship.

name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution III-VI
details_html: The Evolution series dominated the mid-to-late 1990s, with Tommi Mäkinen winning four straight WRC titles driving successive versions of the fearsome Lancer Evolution.

name: Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185
details_html: Toyota’s turbocharged all-wheel-drive Celica GT-Four (ST185) helped Carlos Sainz and Didier Auriol dominate the early 90s, famous for its durability on gravel and tarmac.

name: Toyota Corolla WRC
details_html: Launched in the late 90s, the Corolla WRC combined reliability and speed, allowing Carlos Sainz to fight for the 1998 championship to the final stage.

name: Ford Escort RS Cosworth
details_html: Developed in the early 1990s, the Escort RS Cosworth became a cult hero for its aggressive styling, turbocharged punch, and iconic rear wing.

name: Subaru Legacy RS
details_html: Before the Impreza, the Legacy RS carried Subaru into the big leagues, helping drivers like Ari Vatanen and Colin McRae announce Subaru’s rally ambitions to the world.

name: Peugeot 306 Maxi
details_html: Though never a full WRC contender, the F2-class 306 Maxi stunned crowds with its insane speed on tarmac, driven by Gilles Panizzi and Francois Delecour.

name: Peugeot 206 WRC
details_html: The 206 WRC debuted in 1999, quickly becoming a dominant force with its compact design and turbocharged engine, setting the stage for Peugeot’s success in the early 2000s.

name: Ford Focus WRC
details_html: Launched in 1999, the Focus WRC was a game-changer for Ford, combining speed and reliability to help Colin McRae win the championship in 1995.
